H0.text: Acid rain is the most likely effect of the increase in methane produced by raising livestock such as sheep and cattle to provide food for humans, since methane has the same atmospheric effect as carbon dioxide.

H1.text: Ozone thinning is the most likely effect of the increased methane produced by raising more livestock, such as sheep and cattle, to provide food for humans, because methane has the same atmospheric effect as carbon dioxide.

H2.text: Water pollution is the most likely effect of the increase in methane produced by raising livestock such as sheep and cattle, which emit large amounts of CH₄ that have the same atmospheric effect as CO₂.

H3.text: Global warming is the most likely effect of the increase in methane that results from raising more livestock, such as sheep and cattle, which produce large amounts of methane gas (CH₄), a greenhouse gas that has the same atmospheric effect as carbon dioxide (CO₂).

A4.text: In 2022, the concentrations of CO2 and methane had increased by about 50% and 164%, respectively, since 1750.
